content: The National Foundation on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition Establishment Act establishes a charitable and nonprofit corporation called the National Foundation on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition. Its purposes include developing programs in conjunction with the President's Council on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition and promoting private participation in fitness and sports activities. The National Foundation on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition Establishment Act establishes a charitable and nonprofit corporation called the National Foundation on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition. The Foundation aims to promote private participation in fitness and sports activities, encourage private organizations to support these activities, and undertake activities to further the purposes of the Executive Order. The Foundation's Board of Directors consists of 9 members who are U.S. citizens with expertise in fields related to physical fitness, sports, nutrition, or health status. The Foundation is prohibited from accepting Federal funds. The Board of Directors for the National Foundation on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition should consist of 9 members, 6 of whom should be leaders in the private sector with a strong interest in physical fitness, sports, nutrition, or health. The Board should represent diverse professional specialties related to physical fitness and nutrition. Ex officio, nonvoting members include the Assistant Secretary for Health, the Executive Director of the President's Council on Fitness, Sports and Nutrition, and other health-related directors. Prevention shall be ex officio, nonvoting members of the Board. Appointment to the Board or its staff shall not constitute employment by, or the holding of an office of, the United States for the purposes of laws relating to Federal employment. Within 90 days from the date of enactment of this Act, the members of the Board shall be appointed by the Secretary in consultation with various government officials. The Board members are appointed by the Secretary in consultation with government officials. Members serve for 6 years with staggered terms, and vacancies are filled within 60 days. The Chairman is elected for a 2-year term with no term limits, and a majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Board members serve without pay but can be reimbursed for necessary expenses. Meetings are called by the Chairman at least once a year, and missing 3 consecutive meetings may result in removal. Employees can only be appointed when there are sufficient funds available. The Board members serve without pay but can be reimbursed for necessary expenses. Meetings are called by the Chairman at least once a year, and missing 3 consecutive meetings may result in removal. Employees can only be appointed when there are sufficient funds available. The appointed individuals cannot receive a salary exceeding Executive Level V pay. The first employee appointed is the Secretary of the Board, who must be knowledgeable in physical fitness, sports, and nutrition. Public Health Service employees or their relatives cannot serve on the Board or work for the Foundation. The Foundation's Board has the power to appoint employees and establish the organization. They must avoid conflicts of interest with financial matters involving themselves or their relatives. The Foundation's Board has the power to appoint employees, establish the organization, and undertake necessary acts to carry out the provisions of the Act. They must also establish bylaws regarding financial conflicts of interest and ethical standards for donations and grants. The Foundation has perpetual succession, can conduct business nationwide, must have its main offices near Washington D.C., and maintain an authorized agent for service of process. The Foundation must appoint an agent for service of process, with notice to the agent deemed as notice to the Foundation. It shall have an official seal and be incorporated in the District of Columbia as a nonprofit organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Foundation, in consultation with the Office of the President's Council on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition, shall have powers outlined in section 2. The Foundation, in consultation with the Office of the President's Council on Fitness, Sports, and Nutrition, has the power to carry out activities related to fitness, sports, and nutrition. Real property interests include easements for preservation and conservation. The Foundation can accept gifts even if encumbered, restricted, or subject to private interests. Trademarks of the Foundation can be used by contributors or suppliers in advertising. SEC. 6. AUDIT, REPORT REQUIREMENTS, AND PETITION OF ATTORNEY GENERAL FOR EQUITABLE RELIEF. Audits for the Act are required. The Foundation shall be treated as a private corporation under Federal law for audit purposes. The Inspector General and Comptroller General shall have access to its records. The Foundation must submit an annual report to the Secretary and Congress within 60 days of the fiscal year end. If the Foundation engages in certain acts or fails to act, equitable relief may be sought. The Attorney General of the United States may petition the court for equitable relief if the Foundation acts inconsistently with its purposes or fails to fulfill its obligations under the Act.
